I think that metrics are fine when people =
just treat them as a source of information. The place where people mess up =
is when they reflexively assume that particular numbers indicate problems a=
nd that there is some sort of moral imperative to confront all perceived pr=
oblems. The fact is, there is no linkage there other than what we bring to =
the table. People and teams have natural rhythms and we have to take care w=
hen we decide what to optimize. 

The fact that people are less productive =
on one particular day out of the week would not surprise me. If someone tol=
d me that a team was uniformly productive every day of the week, I'd actual=
ly be rather scared of what I might find if I was to visit them.

Michael

>A third way in to the puzzle: in=
formation is not useful until it is
>integrated into a framework of meaning=
. At any given time, any such
>framework has a loose boundary (the so-calle=
d hermeneutic horizon),
>which represents the only possible locations where=
 new information can
>be fit. If the boundary is not situated where the new=
 information can
>be fit in, it will be ignored, hence useless. So it pays =
to focus
>one's attention not just on generating data, but on generating th=
e
>data that will fit the current boundary for the current group and
